comments.commentBody:
I'm not much of an opera fan, so, OK, I finally broke down and learned (some) about Wagner's "Ring" via Wikipedia. I was afraid 39D & 59A were going to be characters, but no, they were easy. 11D is German (umlaut over the "u") for Valkyrie.

56A is usually translated from Latin to English as: Jesus of Nazareth, King (Rex) of the Jews. Early Latin had no J, and only later did the I split to I & J.

And - Yes! - I remember Elston Howard.

-- jpgaskell

McChrystal was responsible for the "command climate" that made it acceptable (to him, anyway) for members of his staff to criticize the President, the Vice President, the National Security Advisor, and foreign diplomatic personnel.

McChrystal, without a doubt, should've known that criticizing or allowing the criticism of the President (or the Vice President) while in military service is a criminal violation of the Uniform Code of Military Justice. The Army provides training on such matters every calendar year.

That being so, McChrystal not only deserved to be relieved and retired, he should've been court-martialed and sent to penal confinement at the Disciplinary Barracks at Fort Leavenworth. He most certainly should not have been retired at four-star rank. He should have been retired, at most, as a two-star, if not as an E-1 private.

Would like to be able to find something good to say about Fusion but I really can't. The most mediocre Japanese dining experience I have ever had. Dirty counter tops, luke-warm tea, service from the dark ages and that's before I talk about the food. I ordered Toro tuna which arrived and looked a sort of bleached off-white - inedible (and expensive). Steak on the hibachi was overcooked, chewy and flavourless. Had to ask for steamed rice 5 times before it came. And to top it all my bill was wrong. Hibachi is an exercise to prove that 'big' and 'good' definitely don't go hand in hand. Avoid.

Outstanding service. trip of a life time. Thanks to Egypt Tours & Travel, of Chicago, Illinois. Very classy tour, personalized and private service. Their web site www.EgyptTours.com
You haven't seen the country, till you tour it privately, getting in-depth into the culture, and getting to see the locals.

did anyone really expect that we taxpayers would recover the money given to GM, Chysler, GMAC, the suppliers etc. etc. etc.?

just be happy that the GM management folks are still spending their paychecks like the old days - too bad the UAW folks had to take a haircut but they can make it up next contract.

The UAW reliant companies are doomed. Even Ford will sooner or later screw itself up like it has done in the past.

Unlike the Koch brothers, who inherited their fortune and have used it to bankroll and create the Tea Party and other noxious right wing pressure groups, both Gates and Buffet earned their fortunes and have used them in inspired and admirable ways. Maybe Gates and Buffet should get together to counter the poisonous effects the Koch brothers are having on our Republic. Donations of several hundred million dollars to left wing groups like Move-On might start to even the political score.

Does it really matter!! Mr.  Bill Gate's has $54 billions and Warren Buffet  has $45 billions ?? . There are still so many people are  dying because of hunger. why we have lost humanity.  i think it is ashamed that we  still consider our self as a human being.
Oh my! The Koch brothers strike again. They must be thrilled to be most likely getting their way come November while the rest of us get screwed by the anti-middle class republicans.
Four of the ten wealthiest Americans are again from the Walton family.  Why isn't Wal-Mart unionized yet?  99% of their workforce draw a sub-poverty wage, just shameless.

I make most of my purchases online, but Ebay is done. I haven't seen a deal worth responding to in quite some time. When exorbitant shipping costs and lengthy response/shipping arrival dates are factored in it is hardly worth the effort.
We should all be "defending the companies stance," except for the fact that we should be "defending the company's stance." It make a difference, when you think about it.
schmidt is a liar.  what an awful facsimile of a human being.  do no harm...sure.  all while being in bed with the NSA.  please pull out of the US market next.

The oly solution to eBay auction business is to overhaul its business model, which is being outdated. Micromanaging it by reducing fees won't work, but first and foremost, online auction from now on should shift away from the current universal online auction to location-based real-time online auction.
After Mr. Schmidt's Verizon no net neutrality statement, I've deleted Google from all my searches. I have not missed them a bit.
it's called the witless protection program....
A little off topic, but hey, why isn't Twitter a choice in the "share" function for Bits?  Is there a Twitter / NYT spat I don't know about?
Who cares? Much ado about nothing.

I found this post in a search for what you might have to say about web-based alternatives to cable tv.

In my Connecticut town, Comcast digital subscribers now have to attach and plug in a converter box to every tv, and our monthly rates have gone from 45/month to 90 and change.

Unimpressed with both of these developments, I am SO ready to ditch comcast. But an antenna gets me few stations, and the reception stutters. A lot. So I will cave in and pay 18/month for the most basic cable service and watch the rest on the net or on netflix.

Too bad my iphone doesn't let me play flash , or I could get my Daily Show and Colbert Report fix by plugging my iphone into my tv's big screen. Same for Hulu (tried the Hulu app; it doesn't get me Stewart or Colbert.)

Between Apple's flash boycott and AT&T's dropped call and weak sigal history, I'm even starting to think about ditching AT&T and my iphone for an android phone. Could I really use the HTC EVO’s HDMI out port to get my shows from the internet to my 32” tv? Could I get a Dell 10” netbook with an HDMI out port and do the same thing - even simultaneously on another tv in another room?

Surely I'm not the only one scheming like this. Is this subject worthy of a column?
It's why I didn't renew my subscription - I felt like, who are they trying to kid, kids ? Thanks so much for writing this blog. I was just too lazy to find the numbers to prove my wondering.

What would have been more interesting is a graph of the last ten years showing the amount of time spent on the internet (FB, Twitter, YouTube, etc) versus the amount of data traveling on the internet. Web pages and applications are serving content that keeps getting richer and richer, but I suspect the amount of time consuming the data hasn't grown nearly as much. A picture is supposed to be worth a thousand words, and thanks to increased bandwidth, we're serving a whole lot more pictures to consumers.

John Epperson

Everyone, in my opinion, should read Huff's "How to Lie with Statistics." First published in '54, it provides a basic foundation for interpreting information, and the story that Wired told with this data is immediately obvious to those who understand Huff's basic points.

Hans on #23. You are right on #14. I could not read it without the alignments which are appropriate now. Your code is more efficient since it only tries to identify three of a type and distinguishes it from the other type.

Pummy on #28,

If the stacks had more coins than 10 each, then we can draw 1, 2, 4, 8, ..... 512 coins from the 10 stacks (say 1 to 10) respectively. The excess weight of the coins over 10230 when represented in binary form gives a number. The positions of 1s in the number give the stacks with the counterfeit coin that is heavier (wonder why anyone would make a heavier counterfeit coin).

Don't know if it is solvable if the stacks have only 10 coins each.

For some reason this article reminded me of the 2003 HBR article by Nicholas Carr tittled "IT Does not Matter". Not because they are related in content (they are not), but because they are unnecessarily sensationalistic.

In what units is "Internet traffic" measured?  I am guessing that the units are megabytes transmitted, which tends to skew the graph in favor of data-intensive applications like Internet video.  If one really wanted to know how people are using the Internet, a more meaningful measure might be time spent on various applications.  If that were the measure, I am guessing that e-mail and web browsing would figure far more prominently, and video would shrink.
